facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 808 and 809 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 808 and 809 of 1963. Appeals by special leave

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated October 5, 1960 of Punjab High Court in Income-tax Reference Nos. 11 and 13 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 5, 1960, of the Punjab High Court in Income-tax Reference Nos. 11 and 13 of 1958.

facts.text: R. D. Aggarwal Company are a registered firm with place of business at Amritsar in Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: R. D. Aggarwal Company-called for the sake of brevity the assessees-are a registered firm having their place of business at Amritsar in the State of Punjab.

facts.text: Assessees carry on business as importers and commission agents for non-resident exporters, specifically Comptoirs Lainiers Osterieth s.a. Anvers Belgium and Filaturae Tessitura Di Tollengno Biella Italy.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees carry on business as importers and as commission agents or non-resident exporters with two of whom we are concerned in these appeals. These two non-resident exporters Comptoirs Lainiers Osterieth s.a. Anvers  Belgium  and Filaturae Tessitura Di Tollengno Biella  Italy  are exporters and manufacturers of worsted woollen yarn.

facts.text: Assessees communicate orders canvassed from dealers in Amritsar to non-residents for acceptance; if contract results, price paid by dealer to non-resident, assessees entitled to commission 1 1/2 to 2 1/2% of price.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees communicate orders canvassed by them from dealers in Amritsar to the non-residents for acceptance if a contract results and price for the goods purchased is paid by the Amritsar dealer to the non-resident exporter, the assessees become entitled to commission varying between 1 1/2 and 2 1/2 of the price.

facts.text: By letter dated March 24, 1951, assessees appointed sole agents for Italian Company for sale of worsted woollen yarns in Indian territories, terminable by one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated March 24, 1951 the assessees were appointed sole agents for the Italian Company for sale of worsted woollen yarns in the Indian territories terminable by one months notice.

facts.text: Assessees to receive 2% commission on net cash amounts from accepted business concluded by their mediation or directly by Italian Company.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees had to maintain the existing customers and to secure new customers conforming to their general terms of sales, and were to receive 2 1 per cent commission on the net cash amounts arising from the accepted business concluded by the mediation of the assessees or directly by the Italian Company with the customers.

facts.text: Belgian Company appointed assessees representatives for whole of India on condition they do not represent other Belgian mill or yarn producer and do not sell Belgian yarn on own account.

anchor.surface_text: The Belgian Company appointed the assessees their representatives for the whole of India on condition that the latter did not represent any other Belgian Mill or yarn producer and did not sell Belgian yam in India on their own account.

facts.text: In assessment year 1952-53, Income-tax Officer C Ward Amritsar added Rs. 54,558 (5% of net total value of yarn sold by non-residents to Indian merchants) to assessees' income deeming business connection.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment of tax in the assessment year 1952-53 the Income-tax Officer, C Ward, Amritsar computed the income of the assessees by adding Rs. 54,558 being 5 of net total value of yam sold by the non-resident companies to Indian merchants in the previous year, because in his view there subsisted business connections between the non- resident exporters and the assessees.

facts.text: ITO orders confirmed in appeal by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The orders passed by the Income-tax Officer were confirmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and also by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: ITAT submitted statement of case to Punjab High Court on two questions regarding business connection under s.42(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal submitted a statement of case to the High Court of Punjab on the following two questions Whether the relationship between the assessee and the non-resident fell within the meaning of the expression business connection as used in S. 42 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: Punjab High Court answered first question in negative and declined to answer second.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the negative and declined to answer the second question.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave, the Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court against the opinion of the High Court in these two cases.

facts.text: Contracts for sale of goods took place outside taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: Turning to the facts of the present case, as found by the revenue authorities, contracts for the sale of goods took place outside the taxable territories, price was received by the nonresidents outside the taxable territories, and delivery was also given outside, the taxable territories.

facts.text: Price received by non-residents outside taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: price was received by the nonresidents outside the taxable territories, and delivery was also given outside, the taxable territories.

facts.text: Delivery of goods given outside taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: and delivery was also given outside, the taxable territories. . No operation such as procuring raw materials, manufacture of finished goods, sale of good or delivery of goods against price took place within the taxable territories

facts.text: No operations such as procuring raw materials, manufacture, sale or delivery took place within taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: No operation such as procuring raw materials, manufacture of finished goods, sale of good or delivery of goods against price took place within the taxable territories the assessees merely procured orders from merchants in Amritsar for purchase of goods from the non-resident companies.

facts.text: Assessees procured orders from merchants in Amritsar, which were offers without authority to accept on behalf of non-residents.

anchor.surface_text: the assessees merely procured orders from merchants in Amritsar for purchase of goods from the non-resident companies. The orders were offers which the assessees had no authority to accept on behalf of the non-residents.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no business connection between assessees and non-residents.

anchor.surface_text: In that view of the case, these appeals must fail and are dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In that view of the case, these appeals must fail and are dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Assessees had no authority to accept orders on behalf of non-residents.

anchor.surface_text: The orders were offers which the assessees had noauthority to accept on behalf of the non-residents. Some commercial activity was undoubtedly carried on by the assessees in the matter of procuring orders

facts.text: Revenue authorities found facts as stated by Supreme Court.

concepts.unlisted_description: Deems income accruing through business connection in taxable territories to arise therein

anchor.surface_text: Section 42, insofar as it is material, provides All income,profits or gains accruing or arising, whether directly or indirectly, through or from any business connection in the taxable territories, shall be deemed to be income accruing or arising within the taxable territories, and where the person entitled to the income, profits or gains is non resident in the taxable territories, shall be chargeable to income-tax either in his name or in the name of his agent, and in the latter case such agent shall be deemed to be, for all the purposes of this Act, the assessee in respect of such income-tax Provided Provided further Provided further Where a person non resident or not ordinarily resident in the taxable territories, carried on business with a person resident in the taxable territories, and it appears to the Income-tax Officer, that owing to the close connection between such persons the course of business is so arranged that the business done by the resident person with the person non resident or not ordinarily resident produces to the resident either no profits or less than the ordinary profits which might be expected to arise in that business, the profits derived therefrom or which may reasonably be deemed to have been derived therefrom, shall be chargeable to income-tax in the name of the resident person who shall be deemed to be, for all the purposes of this Act, the assessee in respect of such income- tax. In the case of a business of which all the operations are not carried out in the taxable territories, the profits and gains of the business deemed under this section to accrue or arise in the taxable territories shall be only such profits and gains as are reasonably attributable to that part of the operations carried out in the taxable territories.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to determine if profits of non-residents taxable through assessees' activities in India

anchor.surface_text: Section 40, insofar as it is material, by sub-s.  2  provides Where the . . . agent of any person non resident in the taxable territories . . . .  such person being hereinafter in this sub- section referred to as a beneficiary  is entitled to receive on behalf of such beneficiary, or is in receipt on behalf of such beneficiary of, any income, profits or gains chargeable under this Act, the tax, if not levied on the beneficiary direct, may be levied upon and recovered from such. . . agent . . . in like manner and to the same amount as it would be leviable upon and recoverable from the beneficiary if in direct receipt of such income, profits or gains.

anchor.surface_text: The only question that falls to be determined in these appeals is whether there was in the two cases between the non-resident companies and the assessees such a relation as may be called business connection, in the taxable territories. If the answer to this question be in the affirmative, the assessees would as statutory agents be chargeable to tax on behalf of the non-resident Companies on profits and gains reasonably attributable to those parts of the operations which were carried on in the taxable territories. The expression business is defined in the Act as any trade, commerce, manufacture or any adventure or concern in the nature of trade, commerce or manufacture, but the Act contains no definition of the expression business connection and its precise connotation is vague and indefinite. The expression business connection undoubtedly means something more than business . A business connection in S. 42 involves a relation between a business carried on by a non-resident which yields profits or gains and some activity in the taxable territories which contributes directly or indirectly to the earning of those profits or gains. It predicates an element of continuity between the business of the non-resident and the activity in the taxable territories a stray or isolated transaction is normally not to be regarded as a business connection.

concepts.interpretation: Involves real and intimate relation of continuity between non-resident's business outside and activity inside taxable territories contributing to profits; mere canvassing orders without authority to contract not sufficient

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: mber ordinarily resident produces to the resident either numberprofits or less than the ordinary profits which might be expected to arise in that busi

anchor.surface_text: The expression business is defined in the Act as any trade, commerce, manufacture or any adventure or concern in the nature of trade, commerce or manufacture

concepts.interpretation: Limits taxable profits to those attributable to operations in taxable territories

A business connection in S. 42 involves a relation between a business carried on by a non-resident which yields profits or gains and some activity in the taxable territories which contributes directly or indirectly to the earning of those profits or gains. It predicates an element of continuity

anchor.surface_text: The expression business connection undoubtedly means something more than business . A business connection in S. 42 involves a relation between a business carried on by a non-resident which yields profits or gains and some activity in the taxable territories which contributes directly or indirectly to the earning of those profits or gains. It predicates an element of continuity between the business of the non-resident and the activity in the taxable territories a stray or isolated transaction is normally not to be regarded as a business connection.

arguments.claim: In Hira Mills case brokers canvassed orders without authority to accept, sales at Ujjain outside territories: no business connection

anchor.surface_text: In Hira Mills Ltd., Cawnpore v. Income-tax Officer, Cawn- pore a non-resident Company carried on business of manufacturing cloth at Ujjain in the Indian State of Gwalior and sent cloth to Cawnpore in British India. Goods were sold by the Companys salesman at Cawnpore and the sale proceeds were collected by him at Cawnpore. ... the Allahabad High Court held that there was no business connection in British India.

arguments.claim: In Abdullabhai case commission agent entered into transactions within territories on behalf of non-resident: business connection; distinction here as assessees had no such authority

anchor.surface_text: In Abdullabhai Abdul Kadar v. Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City the assessee acted as commission agent of a nonresident and entered into transactions within the taxable territories on behalf of the non-resident ... It was held that there was a business connection ... The distinction between Abdullabhai Abdul Kadars case and the Hira Mills case may be noticed. In the former the commission agents had purchased cloth in the taxable territories for the non-resident

arguments.claim: In Bangalore Woollen managing agents bought raw materials, sold goods, collected proceeds in territories: business connection; distinction as here no such activities

anchor.surface_text: In Bangalore Woollen, Cotton and Silk Mills Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras the assessee a Company registered in the Indian State of Mysore ... the agents bought raw materials ... received the sale proceeds ... This was a clear case of a business connection in British India

arguments.claim: In Anglo-French Textile constituted agent made all purchases of cotton in territories: business connection; distinction as here no purchases or sales by assessees

anchor.surface_text: Then there is a decision of this Court Anglo-French Textile Company Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras . The assessee had appointed another limited Company in Madras as its constituted agent ... all the purchases of cotton required for the factory at Pondicherry were made by the agents in British India ... the assessee Company had a business connection in British India

arguments.claim: contracts for the sale of goods took place outside the taxable territories, price was received by the nonresidents outside the taxable territories, and delivery was also given outside, the taxable territories. No operation such as procuring raw materials, manufacture of finished goods, sale of good or delivery of goods against price took place within the taxable territories; assessees merely procured orders which were offers without authority to accept: no business connection

anchor.surface_text: Turning to the facts of the present case, as found by the revenue authorities, contracts for the sale of goods took place outside the taxable territories, price was received by the nonresidents outside the taxable territories, and delivery was also given outside, the taxable territories. . No operation such as procuring raw materials, manufacture of finished goods, sale of good or delivery of goods against price took place within the taxable territories the assessees merely procured orders from merchants in Amritsar for purchase of goods from the non-resident companies. The orders were offers which the assessees had no authority to accept on behalf of the non-residents.

holdings.text: there was in the two cases between the non-resident companies and the assessees ... no such a relation as may be called business connection, in the taxable territories

anchor.surface_text: The only question that falls to be determined in these appeals is whether there was in the two cases between the non-resident companies and the assessees such a relation as may be called business connection, in the taxable territories.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restated the sole issue; applied statutory interpretation of business connection requiring continuity and contribution to profits; reviewed and distinguished precedents (e.g., Hira Mills analogous, Abdullabhai distinguished); facts show mere order canvassing without acceptance authority, all contracts/prices/delivery outside territories

holdings.text: The expression business connection undoubtedly means something more than business. A business connection in S. 42 involves a relation between a business carried on by a non-resident which yields profits or gains and some activity in the taxable territories which contributes directly or indirectly to the earning of those profits or gains. It predicates an element of continuity between the business of the non-resident and the activity in the taxable territories; a stray or isolated transaction is normally not to be regarded as a business connection

anchor.surface_text: The expression business connection undoubtedly means something more than business . A business connection in S. 42 involves a relation between a business carried on by a non-resident which yields profits or gains and some activity in the taxable territories which contributes directly or indirectly to the earning of those profits or gains. It predicates an element of continuity between the business of the non-resident and the activity in the taxable territories a stray or isolated transaction is normally not to be regarded as a business connection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation of undefined term in s.42(1); more than mere business, requires intimate continuous relation contributing to non-resident's profits; supported by review of precedents illustrating forms of connection

holdings.text: sub-ss. 2 and 3 illustrate special cases of business connections and do not purport to limit the connotation of that expression

anchor.surface_text: In the case of a business of which all the operations are not carried out in the taxable territories, the profits and gains of the business deemed under this section to accrue or arise in the taxable territories shall be only such profits and gains as are reasonably attributable to that part of the operations carried out in the taxable territories. It may be observed that sub-ss. 2 and 3 illustrate special cases of business connections and do

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory construction of s.42 provisos as illustrative examples rather than exhaustive definition of business connection

holdings.text: But on this account no business connection of the assessees with the non-residents within the taxable territories resulted

anchor.surface_text: Some commercial activity was undoubtedly carried on by the assessees in the matter of procuring orders which resulted in contracts for sale by the nonresidents of goods to merchants at Amritsar. But on this account no business connection of the assessees with the non-residents within the taxable territories resulted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied business connection test to undisputed facts (f14-f18,f21): orders mere offers without acceptance authority; no operations (manufacture,sale,delivery) in territories; activity preliminary and non-contributory to profits in intimate/continuous manner

holdings.text: The expression business connection postulates a real and intimate relation between trading activity carried on outside the taxable territories and trading activity within the territories, the relation between the two contributing to the earning of income by the non-resident in his trading activity. In this case such a relation is absent

anchor.surface_text: The expression business connection postulates a real and intimate relation between trading activity carried on outside the taxable territories and trading activity within the territories, the relation between the two contributing to the earning of income by the non- resident in his trading activity. In this case such a relation is absent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirmed interpretation via rule-to-facts application; distinguished from cases with agent authority for purchases/sales inside territories (Bangalore Woollen, Anglo-French, Abdullabhai)

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Remington Typewriters Co. Bombay Ltd.1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Remington Typewriters Co. Bombay Ltd.1 a Company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, which was a subsidiary of an American Company was deemed for the purposes of the Indian Income-tax Act to be the statutory agent of the latter Company and was charged to tax under s. 42  1   in respect of profits made by that Company upon machines exported to the taxable territories and in respect of dividends received from the Indian Company, although the assessee Company was number an agent for the American Company L.R. 58 I.A. 42.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Remington Typewriters Co. Bombay Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: business connection existed between non-resident American company and its Indian subsidiary involving transfer of goodwill, export of machines for sale, and receipt of dividends
precedents.cited_holding: profits from sale of machines and dividends taxable under s. 42(1) despite no agency under s. 40

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay Presidency and Aden v. Currimbhoy Ebrahim and Sons Ltd.1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay Presidency and Aden v. Currimbhoy Ebrahim and Sons Ltd.1 advance of a loan by a number-resident was held number to be a business companynection.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay Presidency and Aden v. Currimbhoy Ebrahim and Sons Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: advance of a loan by a non-resident does not constitute a business connection
precedents.cited_holding: loan transaction was isolated; no business connection between lender and borrower; interest not taxable under s. 42(1)

precedents.case_name: Bangalore Woollen, Cotton and Silk Mills Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras

precedents.cited_holding: profits attributable to activities in British India taxable under s. 42

precedents.citation: Abdullabhai Abdul Kadar v. Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City 1

anchor.surface_text: Abdullabhai Abdul Kadar v. Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City 1  the assessee acted as companymission agent of a numberresident and entered into transactions within the taxable territories on behalf of the number-resident, but he was number the sole companymissions agent of the number-resident who did business through other agents as well.

precedents.case_name: Abdullabhai Abdul Kadar v. Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: commission agency need not be exclusive to constitute business connection; requires element of continuity
precedents.cited_holding: business connection existed despite multiple agents

The assesses Company incorporated in the United Kingdom owned a spinning and weaving factory at Pondicherry in French India. The assessee had appointed another limited Company in Madras as its companystituted agent for the purpose of its business in British India.

precedents.cited_proposition: constituted agent making all purchases of raw materials (cotton) in taxable territories constitutes business connection
precedents.cited_holding: portion of profits attributable to purchases in British India taxable under s. 42(3)

Section 4(1) Income-tax Act, charging tax on income accruing or arising or deemed within taxable territories, addresses the issue of whether such profits accrued or arose or deemed.

Section 42(3) Income-tax Act limits taxable profits to those attributable to operations in taxable territories, which directly addresses the issue of whether profits or gains accrued, arose, or were deemed to have done so on the facts of the case.

The fact of no operations such as procuring raw materials, manufacture, sale or delivery within taxable territories negates the accrual, arising, or deeming of income within taxable territories required for Section 4(1).
The fact that no operations took place within taxable territories directly addresses the issue of whether profits or gains accrued, arose, or could be deemed to have on the facts and circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Some commercial activity was undoubtedly carried on by the assessees in the matter of procuring orders which resulted in contracts for sale by the nonresidents of goods to merchants at Amritsar. But on this account no business connection of the assessees with the non-residents within the taxable territories resulted.
In that view of the case, these appeals must fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: e authorities, companytracts for the sale of goods took place outside the taxable territories, price was received by the numberresidents outside the t

edges.explanation: The holding defines 'business connection', directly relevant to the issue's inquiry

anchor.surface_text: The expression business connection postulates a real and intimate relation between trading activity carried on outside the taxable territories and trading activity within the territories, the relation between the two contributing to the earning of income by the non- resident in his trading activity. In this case such a relation is absent.
In that view of the case, these appeals must fail and are dismissed with costs.
